body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X^2 + 2011 = Y^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"\nwhere X and Y are both positive integers.\nFind value of 3X + Y"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (Y - X)( Y + X) = 2011 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since 2011 is prime, we have:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" Y - X = 1 \quad and \quad Y + X = 2011"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Then
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" Y = 1006  \quad and \quad  X = 1005"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { 1 }^{ 2 }+3={ 2 }^{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { 2 }^{ 2 }+5={ 3 }^{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { 3 }^{ 2 }+7={ 4}^{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"... "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" { X }^{ 2 }+2011={ Y }^{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"From the pattern we can clearly tell that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2011=2Y-1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2Y=2012"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Y=1006"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". From the pattern, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" X=Y-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X = 1005"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 3X+Y = 3\times 1005+1006=4021 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            a little more care should be taken... for example,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1^2+15=4^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^2+21=5^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"etc."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In general, you could write "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2+2011=(x+a)^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Expanding, you get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2011=a(2x+a)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since 2011 is prime, we must have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x+a=2011"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=1005, y=1006"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3x+y=4021"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Although this wasn't so right to solve, but this pattern actually came in my mind and helped me solved this question.
I observed the pattern of the difference in square of two subsequence numbers is the sum of the two subsequence number when I was still small.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 2011 Korean CSAT Exam #16
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/Wm2ENAEW9g-d83f21a1-9ad3-488e-adf7-1ce82e1d8357.jpeg?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
Denote three points as the following: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(x_1,y_1), Q(x_2,y_2), R(x_3,y_3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using the diagram above, which of the following inequalities is/are TRUE? ("},{"type":"text","text":"Do NOT use a calculator. NO CHEATING!","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":")"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1.)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\quad \dfrac12<x_1<1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(2.)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\quad x_2<2x_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3.)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \quad  x_2(x_1-1)>y_1(y_2-1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This was the original statement. Therefore R was denoted in the original context."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2012 AIME I Problem 3
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Nine people sit down for dinner where there are three choices of meals. Three people order the beef meal, three order the chicken meal, and three order the fish meal. The waiter serves the nine meals in random order. Find the number of ways in which the waiter could serve the meal types to the nine people so that exactly one person receives the type of meal ordered by that person."}]}]}
